item.title: Majority Think Trump Off to Fair-Poor Start: NBC News/WSJ Poll
item.dc:creator: Mark Murray
item.description: Sixty-four percent of Americans say President Donald Trump is off to a poor or fair start in his first 100 days while 35 percent say the beginning of his presidency has been good or great, according to a new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll. Trump's approval rating stands at 40 percent, the poll showed, in what is the lowest for any president at this point in office.

media:content.media:text: Image: Trump surprised many with his strong condemnation of the suspect gas attack in Syria, and is weighing a response
media:content.media:description: Trump surprised many with his strong comments on Syria.

item.title: AG Sessions on Hawaii Remark: 'Nobody Has a Sense of Humor Anymore'
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Last week, Sessions criticized a federal judge's ruling in Hawaii that blocked the Trump administration's immigration ban.

media:content.media:text: Image: Attorney General Jeff Sessions
media:content.media:description: Attorney General Jeff Sessions answers questions during a press conference at the Department of Justice on Thursday.

item.title: Erin Moran, Who Played Joanie on 'Happy Days', Dead at 56
item.dc:creator: Phil Helsel and Gemma DiCasimirro
item.description: Erin Moran, who played Richie Cunningham's little sister in "Happy Days" was found dead Saturday, the Harrison County, Indiana, sheriff's office said.

media:content.media:text: Image: Erin Moran
media:content.media:description: In this Sept. 24, 2008 file photo, Erin Moran is seen arriving at the Fox Reality Channel Really Awards in Los Angeles.

media:content.media:text: The Fox Reality Channel Really Awards - Arrivals
media:content.media:description: In this Sept. 24, 2008 file photo, Erin Moran is seen at the Fox Reality Channel Really Awards in Hollywood, Calif.

media:content.media:text: Garry Marshall, Tom Bosley, Marion Ross, Erin Moran, Henry Winkler, Anson Williams
media:content.media:description: In this July 12, 2001 file photo, Garry Marshall, from left, Tom Bosley, Marion Ross, Erin Moran, Henry Winkler, and Anson Williams of the television show "Happy Days," pose after Ross received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

item.title: N. Korea Threatens Australia With Nuclear Strike Over 'Toeing Line' With U.S.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Hubbard and Eric Baculinao
item.description: A spokesman for the North Korean foreign ministry accused Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop of spouting "a string of rubbish against the DPRK (Democratic People's Republic of Korea)."

item.title: French Elections: Marine Le Pen Backed By Quiet Army of Women
item.dc:creator: Saphora Smith
item.description: There is a quiet army on the march in France — female National Front supporters — who could well tip the balance of the election and send the hard-right party to the presidency.

media:content.media:text: Image: Marine Le Pen campaign rally in Paris
media:content.media:description: Le Pen waves at the audience after speaking at a rally in Paris on April 17.

media:content.media:text: Image: Jennifer Troin, 29, is a sales assistant in a children's clothes store in Cogolin on April 13, 2017
media:content.media:description: Jennifer Troin, 29, is a sales assistant in a children's clothes store in Cogolin, France on April 13, 2017.

media:content.media:text: Image: French far-right Front National leader Marine Le Pen is kissed by her father Jean-Marie Le Pen
media:content.media:description: Front National leader Marine Le Pen is kissed by her father Jean-Marie Le Pen after being re-elected as president of the party on Nov. 30, 2014.

media:content.media:text: Image: Marine Le Pen supporters cheer
media:content.media:description: Marine Le Pen supporters cheer at a rally in the southern city of Marseille on Wednesday.

media:content.media:text: Image: Mayor Marc Etienne Lansade sits at his desk
media:content.media:description: Cogolin's mayor Marc Etienne Lansade sits at his desk.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi: Border Wall Is 'Immoral, Expensive, Unwise'
item.dc:creator: Kailani Koenig
item.description: While a deal to fund the government this week won't necessarily include funding for the construction of a complete border wall, White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus on Sunday said there will be "enough to get going" — even as House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi called it "immoral."

item.title: Poll: Record Number of Americans Say Government 'Should Do More'
item.dc:creator: Carrie Dann
item.description: A record number of Americans now say that the government should do more — not less — in order to solve the nation's problems.

media:content.media:text: Image: Congressional Majority In Question As Election Nears
media:content.media:description: The Senate side of the US Capitol is shown October 11, 2016 in Washington D.C. House and Senate Republicans are in a close race with Democrats to keep control of both houses of Congress.

item.title: American Member of Watchdog Group Killed in Ukraine
item.description: A U.S. member of European security watchdog OSCE's monitoring mission in eastern Ukraine was killed after a vehicle he was in drove over a mine.

media:content.media:text: Image: An official of the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine has died after his car blew up when he drove over a mine near the village of Prishib, Slavyanoserbsk District, Lugansk People's Republic, Ukraine, April 23, 2017.
media:content.media:description: An official of the OSCE (Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe) Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine has died after his car blew up when he drove over a mine near the village of Prishib, Slavyanoserbsk District, Lugansk People's Republic, Ukraine, April 23, 2017.

media:content.media:text: Image: An official of the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine has died after his car blew up when he drove over a mine near the village of Prishib, Slavyanoserbsk District, Lugansk People's Republic, Ukraine, April 23, 2017.
media:content.media:description: An official of the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine was killed when this car drove over a mine near the village of Prishib, Ukraine, April 23, 2017.

item.title: France Goes to Polls Amid Tight Security Following Paris Attack
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: More than 60,000 polling stations opened amid tight security across the country on Sunday, following an attack in Paris on Thursday which left a police officer dead.

media:content.media:text: Image: FRANCE2017-VOTE
media:content.media:description: Louis Aliot, one of the vice-presidents of the French far-right National Front (FN) party, walks past electoral posters in Perpignan.

media:content.media:text: Image: An undated family handout released by the French police headquarters on April 22, 2017, shows Xavier Jugele, the French policeman killed during the attack on the Champs Elysees Avenue in Paris, on April 20, 2017.
media:content.media:description: Xavier Jugele, the French policeman killed during the attack on the Champs Elysees Avenue in Paris.

media:content.media:text: Image: FRANCE2017-VOTE
media:content.media:description: Louis Aliot, one of the vice-presidents of the French far-right National Front (FN) party, walks past electoral posters in Perpignan.

item.dc:creator: Avalon Zoppo and Shamar Walters
item.description: American Airlines is investigating after a video showed the aftermath of an argument between a flight attendant and a sobbing woman passenger.

item.title: Inside The Home of the Mass Jewish Bomb-Threat Suspect
item.dc:creator: Paul Goldman
item.description: It was here, in an apartment in the Israeli city of Ashkelon, that officials say a Israeli-American Jewish teenager wrecked havoc across America.

media:content.media:text: U.S.-Israeli teen arrested in Israel on suspicion of making bomb threats against Jewish community centres in the United States, Australia and New Zealand is escorted by security personnel following his hearing at Magistrate's Court in Rishon Lezion
media:content.media:description: U.S.-Israeli teen arrested in Israel is escorted by security personnel following his remand hearing at Magistrate's Court in Rishon Lezion, Israel, on March 23, 2017.

item.title: North Korea Detains Third American Citizen: Officials
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: The Swedish Embassy in Pyongyang said it was aware of a Korean-American citizen being detained recently, but could not comment further.

item.title: Golf Balls in Hash Browns Lead to Recall
item.description: McCain Foods USA's recall notice said the golf balls apparently were "inadvertently harvested" along with the potatoes and chopped up.

item.title: March for Science Protesters Say They're the Real Patriots
item.dc:creator: Maggie Fox
item.description: Lovers of science got their day in the rain Saturday as they cheered their passions.

media:content.media:text: Image: Alison Wolf of Richmond, Virginia studies tobacco and nicotine at Virginia Commonwealth University. She said she wanted to stress that science is part of society's mainstream. She carried a sign saying, "Cells divide. Do we have to?"
media:content.media:description: Alison Wolf of Richmond, Virginia studies tobacco and nicotine at Virginia Commonwealth University. She said she wanted to stress that science is part of society's mainstream. She carried a sign saying, "Cells divide. Do we have to?"

media:content.media:text: Image: "Government and religion are separate. Science and religion should be separate," said Ileana Modesto, a preschool teacher from Alexandria, Virginia.
media:content.media:description: "Government and religion are separate. Science and religion should be separate," said Ileana Modesto, a preschool teacher from Alexandria, Virginia.

media:content.media:text: Image: Protesters entertained one another as they made their points with home-made signs along Constitution Avenue in Washington.
media:content.media:description: Protesters entertained one another as they made their points with home-made signs along Constitution Avenue in Washington. Most, like these using periodic table symbols for elements, used science-themed puns. NBC News estimates that at least 10,000 people turned out in a steady downpour to cheer on speakers at the March for Science and then shuffle slowly along Constitution Avenue, passing the Washington monument, the White House and other landmarks in the capital.

media:content.media:text: Image: Alison Wolf of Richmond, Virginia studies tobacco and nicotine at Virginia Commonwealth University. She said she wanted to stress that science is part of society's mainstream. She carried a sign saying, "Cells divide. Do we have to?"
media:content.media:description: Alison Wolf of Richmond, Virginia studies tobacco and nicotine at Virginia Commonwealth University. She said she wanted to stress that science is part of society's mainstream. She carried a sign saying, "Cells divide. Do we have to?"

item.title: Border Wall 'Catastrophic' for Endangered Species: Activists
item.dc:creator: Daniella Silva and Suzanne Gamboa
item.description: Scientists and conservationists said such drastic increases in border security could be devastating for hundreds of species.

media:content.media:text: Image: A jaguar is pictured in its enclosure during a summer day at the Los Angeles Zoo
media:content.media:description: A jaguar is pictured in its enclosure during a summer day at the Los Angeles Zoo in Los Angeles, California U.S., August 13, 2016. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni

media:content.media:credit: University of Arizona/U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
media:content.media:text: Image: Adult male jaguar photographed in southern Arizona by motion-detection wildlife monitoring cameras
media:content.media:description: Adult male jaguar photographed in the Santa Rita Mountains on July 30, 2015 by motion-detection wildlife monitoring cameras.

media:content.media:text: Image: Mexican Gray Wolf
media:content.media:description: A female Mexican gray wolf at the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge in central N.M on Dec. 11, 2011.

media:content.media:text: Image: Steel walls, fences, razor wire and other barricades on the US-Mexico border
media:content.media:description: Multiple layers of steel walls, fences, razor wire and other barricades are viewed from the United States side of the of the US-Mexico border in San Ysidro, California on Jan. 26, 2017.

media:content.media:text: Image: Existing border wall and jaguar movement corridors
media:content.media:description: Existing border wall and jaguar movement corridors.
The border fence built by the George W. Bush administration stretches along land in Brownsville and in front of the sanctuary, that is behind the fence but still in the United States.
The view of the wetland wildlife habitat and water fowl through the Resaca blind in the Sabal Palm Sanctuary in Brownsville, Texas.

media:content.media:text: Image: Tourists walk in the water of the Rio Grande River in Big Bend National Park in Texas
media:content.media:description: Tourists walk in the water of the Rio Grande, along a cliff face that is Mexico, left, as they vacation at Big Bend National Park in Texas on March 27.

item.dc:creator: Chelsea Bailey
item.description: Many in the Berkeley community feel that recent clashes have turned their city into a powder-keg on the brink.
